titleText.ttltext: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end diseases and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage among migrants and non-migrants worldwide: A scoping @hit_startreview@hit_end of published @hit_startliterature@hit_end, 2006 to 2016

organizations: Department of Public Health, Auckland University of Technology

paras: Background: Studies of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end disease (VPD)burden and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage among migrants compared to locally-born populations present a mixed picture on whether migrants experience disproportionate VPD rates and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end inequities, and what the associated factors are. We conducted a scoping review to explore differences in VPD burden and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage between migrants and non-migrants worldwide. Methods: We followed Arksey and O'Malley's five stage scoping review method. We searched for empirical, peer-@hit_startreviewed literature@hit_end published in English that compared VPD burden and/or @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end coverage between migrant and non-migrant groups published between 2006 and 2016 using @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, Sociological Abstracts, and Web of Science databases. Relevant information from the studies were charted in Microsoft Excel and results were summarised using a descriptive @hit_startanalytical@hit_end method. Results: Forty-five studies met the inclusion criteria (n = 13 reporting on VPD burden; n = 27 reporting on @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates; n = 5 reporting on both). Studies that met the criteria only reported findings from high income countries or high-middle income countries. Accounting for results that were presented according to separate ethnic migrant sub-groups, almost all of the studies comparing VPD burden (n = 17, 89%)reported higher burden among migrants compared to non-migrants, while most studies measuring @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates (n = 26, 70%)noted lower rates among migrants. Numerous factors contributed to these findings, including the influence of migrants’ nativity, socio-economic status, migration background, generation status, residential duration, cultural/personal beliefs, language proficiency and healthcare utilisation. Conclusions: Considerable variability of study foci and methodologies limited our ability to make definitive conclusions and comparisons, but the literature suggests that migrant populations generally experience higher VPD burden and lower @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates. The findings highlight a number of important considerations for future research and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end programme planning. Future research should explore factors that influence VPD burden and @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end rates, and strategies to overcome barriers to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake among migrants.

titleText.ttltext: Prevalence and dynamics of missed opportunities for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end among children in Africa: applying systems thinking in a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of observational studies

organizations: Centre for Evidence-based Health Care, Division of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Department of Global Health, Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, Stellenbosch University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Objective: To estimate the prevalence of missed opportunities for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (MOV) among children aged 0–23 months attending health-care facilities in Africa and explore the factors responsible for MOV using systems thinking. Research design and methods: We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of studies reporting the proportion MOVs. Five electronic databases were searched. A random effects model was fitted to obtain pooled estimates of MOV and a causal loop diagram (CLD) was constructed to explore the dynamics of the causes of MOV. MOV was defined as any contact with health services in Africa, by an unvaccinated or under-@hit_startvaccinated@hit_end child, aged 0–23 months, who is eligible for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and free of any contraindication, which does not result in @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Results: Four hundred and twenty-one publications were found, of which 20 studies from 14 countries were included. The pooled prevalence of MOV was estimated to be 27.26% (95%CI: 18.80–36.62). A CLD with seven reinforcing and two balancing loops were constructed. Conclusion: Our findings suggest that about one in every four children under the age of two years who visited health facilities in 14 African countries missed the @hit_startvaccination@hit_end they were eligible to receive. To enable continent-wide estimates, more MOV assessments are required.

titleText.ttltext: α-Lipoic acid, functional fatty acid, as a novel therapeutic alternative for central nervous system diseases: A review

organizations: Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Research Center, Tabriz University of Medical Sciences

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2017, © 2017 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Objectives: α-lipoic acid (ALA) is a natural antioxidant which acts as a cofactor of bioenergetic mitochondrial enzymes. Along with its mitochondrial action, ALA and its reduced form have many biological functions resulting in a wide variety of actions such as anti-inflammation and antioxidant protection, scavenging reactive oxygen species, regenerating other antioxidant agents, such as vitamins C and E, and cytosolic glutathione, chelating the transitional metal ions (e.g. iron and copper), and modulating the signal transduction of nuclear factor. Methods: By selecting papers from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Science Direct, EBSCO, and databases, this review discusses the biochemical properties of LA, its mechanism of action, pharmacokinetics, and its possible therapeutic role in central nervous system diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, Multiple sclerosis, stroke, and spinal cord injury. Results: ALA as an antioxidant and anti-inflammation agent has therapeutical effects on central nervous system diseases, especially multiple sclerosis and PD. Discussion: ALA can be considered as a potentially useful treatment in central nervous disorders.

titleText.ttltext: The burden of pertussis in older adults: what is the role of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end? A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 The Author(s). Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Pertussis (whooping cough) is a @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end disease; however, neither natural- nor @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-induced@hit_end protection is life-long. Although generally not severe in adults, pertussis can be associated with complications in patients with chronic conditions such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and can be readily transmitted to more vulnerable populations, including neonates before they complete their primary @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Furthermore, as the global population ages, the health and economic burden of the disease is expected to rise. Areas covered: A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end was conducted to ascertain the current epidemiological and financial burden of pertussis in older adults and to discuss the potential value of a booster @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in this population. Expert commentary: Our review indicates a considerable underestimation of the pertussis burden amongst older adults. Seroprevalence studies consistently demonstrate that the reported incidence may be much lower than the actual incidence. Tetanus toxoid-reduced diphtheria toxoid and acellular pertussis @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are immunogenic in older adults, induce high booster responses and are well-tolerated. There is therefore a good rationale for the advocacy of booster pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end throughout life to prevent pertussis infection and its transmission, especially in adults aged ≥50 years.

titleText.ttltext: Burden of varicella in the Asia-Pacific region: a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end

organizations: Department of Paediatrics, KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 The Author(s). Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Varicella is a highly contagious infection that can lead to serious complications, particularly in high-risk groups; however, it is @hit_startvaccine@hit_end preventable. Disease awareness and understanding of the disease burden can strongly influence @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage. This review provides insight into the current epidemiology and the importance of varicella from both public health and economic perspectives across the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region. Areas covered: A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end was conducted to identify studies on the incidence, seroprevalence, fatality rate and complication rate of varicella. Economic burden studies were also captured. Altogether, 125 studies were identified across the region; these were supplemented by government reports (gray data). Reported @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage varied from 2.8% to 97%; a key influencing factor was inclusion of the varicella @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in national @hit_startimmunization@hit_end programs. In general, varicella incidence in the unvaccinated population was highest in children ≤5 years old and seroprevalence increased with age. Economic @hit_startanalyses@hit_end highlighted the cost-saving potential of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs, especially from a societal perspective. Expert opinion: Varicella-related data varied greatly across the APAC region, highlighting the need to better understand the burden of varicella in this area, and particularly identified the need for better surveillance and reporting.

titleText.ttltext: Update on @hit_startvaccination@hit_end of preterm infants: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end about safety and efficacy/effectiveness. Proposal for a position statement by Italian Society of Pediatric Allergology and Immunology jointly with the Italian Society of Neonatology.

organizations: Pediatric Infectious Disease Unit, Anna Meyer Children’s University Hospital

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, © 2019 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
paras: Introduction: Preterm infants (PIs) are at increased risk of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-preventable@hit_end diseases (VPDs). However, delayed @hit_startvaccination@hit_end start and low @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage are still reported. Areas covered: This @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end includes 37 articles on preterm @hit_startvaccination@hit_end published in 2008–2018 in @hit_startPubMed@hit_end. Both live attenuated and inactivated @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are safe and well tolerated in PIs. Local reactions, apnea, and reactivity changes are the most frequently reported adverse events. Lower gestational age and birth weight, preimmunization apnea, longer use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) are risk factors for apnea. The proportion of PIs who develop protective humoral and cellular @hit_startimmunity@hit_end is generally similar to full terms although later gestational age is associated with increased antibody IgG concentrations (i.e. against certain pneumococcal serotypes, influenza, hepatitis B virus and poliovirus 1) and increased mononuclear cells proliferation (i.e. after inactivated poliovirus). Expert opinion: PIs can be safely and adequately protected by available @hit_startvaccines@hit_end with the same schedule used for full terms. Data at this regard have been retrieved by studies using a 3-dose primary series for pneumococcal and hexavalent @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Further studies are needed regarding the 2 + 1 schedule. Apnea represents a nonspecific stress response in PIs, thus those hospitalized at 2 months should have cardio-respiratory monitoring after their first @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Use of adjuvanted trivalent influenza @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in older-age adults: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of economic evidence

organizations: Department of Public Health, University of Naples “Federico II”

paras: Seasonal influenza is a very common disease. Yearly @hit_startvaccination@hit_end of at-risk population groups is a well-recognized cost-effective/cost-saving preventive measure. It is, however, unclear which available alternative has the most favorable economic profile. Some available options are: trivalent (TIV) and quadrivalent (QIV) inactivated @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, adjuvanted TIV (aTIV). Because of immunosenescence, aTIV has been specifically developed for elderly. The present study aimed at assessing the available evidence of aTIV use in elderly from the economic perspective. A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end targeting aTIV economic evaluations in adults aged ≥65 years was performed using @hit_startMedline@hit_end via Ovid, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, DARE and NHS/EED. Of a total of 3,654 papers screened, 18 studies (13 full papers, 5 conference abstracts) were included. It emerged that compared with both non-@hit_startvaccination@hit_end or non-adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, aTIV was cost-effective or cost-saving. The @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end strategies incorporating aTIV based on age and/or risk profile are associated with the most favorable economic outcomes.

titleText.ttltext: Choosing Pre-conception Planning for Women/Families: Counselling and Informed Consent (Part 2) – Pre-conception Reproductive Planning, Lifestyle, @hit_startImmunization@hit_end, and Psychosocial Issues

organizations: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Cumming School of Medicine University of Calgary

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2017 The Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada/La Société des obstétriciens et gynécologues du Canada.
paras: Objective: To inform reproductive and other health care providers about pre-conception evaluation, including considerations for reproductive planning, lifestyle modification, @hit_startimmunization@hit_end status and attitudes, and psychosocial issues. Options: This counselling information can be used for patient education and planning and possible pre-conception and/or prenatal testing. Outcomes: This information may allow for improved risk assessment when pre-conception counselling for individual patients and their families is used. Considerations for Pre-conception Care (Part 2) Regarding Pre-conception Reproductive Planning, Lifestyle, Immunizations, and Psychosocial Issues: 1 The health provider should obtain a medical and surgical history from the patient with more detailed information regarding her personal and family gynaecological and oncology history (Strong/Moderate) (III-A). 2 The health provider needs to determine from the patient whether pregnancy planning or prevention is a primary consideration at each office visit. The provider should offer to educate and counsel the patient about the personal use of and options available for birth control to enhance the patient's reproductive planning and her ability to achieve pregnancy when it is desired (Strong/Moderate) (III-A). 3 The health provider of regular or intermittent women's obstetrical and gynaecology health care should encourage women, with their reproductive partner, to consider and discuss their personal reproductive planning needs. Patient autonomy and knowledge about their reproductive options and anticipated maternity care are important factors for parents because the opportunity to enable the “healthiest pregnancy possible” is what will give the best start in life to their children and their family (Strong/Moderate) (III-A). 4 The health provider needs to inquire about and then educate and counsel the patient if there is a history of anxiety, stress, and/or depression in the patient's personal history because these may increase the risk of a pregnancy or postpartum exacerbation requiring maternal medication with chronic fetal exposure and with neonatal withdrawal effects (Strong/Moderate) (III-A). 5 Preventive health activities require assessment and discussion of the patient's @hit_startimmunization@hit_end thoughts, practices, and personal @hit_startimmunity@hit_end status for infectious “at risk” conditions. The @hit_startimmunization@hit_end status can affect both maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality (Strong/Moderate) (III-A). 6 The health provider needs to inquire about and then educate and counsel the patient when certain lifestyle risks are identified, such as caffeine consumption (increased intake); frequent smoking activity (tobacco, marijuana); regular or binge alcohol usage; regular or high-risk intermittent street drug usage; and workplace exposures (Strong/Moderate) (III-A). Consideration for Care Statements: For this review article, the Consideration for Care Statements use the Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development and Evaluations strength and quality principles because they are comparable for the clinician and the patient/public user. For example, “Strong” for clinicians is defined as “the recommendation would apply to most individuals. Formal discussion aids are not likely to be needed to help individuals make decisions consistent with their values and preferences.” For patients/the public, “Strong” is defined as, “we believe most people in this situation would want the recommended course of actions and only a small number would not.” Quality of evidence (High, Moderate, Low) is based on the confidence that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect. In addition, the Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care key to evidence statements and grading of recommendations are included. Evidence: @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startMedline@hit_end, and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Database were searched until May 2017, using appropriate key words (i.e., preconception, reproductive planning, lifestyle modification, @hit_startimmunization@hit_end risks and benefits, psychosocial pregnancy factors/issues). Grey (unpublished) literature was identified through searching websites of health technology assessment and health technology assessment–related agencies, clinical practice guideline collections, and national and international medical specialty societies. Benefits, harms, and costs: The benefits for the patient and her family from receiving this pre-conception counseling would include an increased understanding of the relevant issues for both pre-conception and in early pregnancy as well as better pregnancy outcomes. Harm includes potential increased anxiety or psychological stress associated with the possibility of identifying maternal pregnancy risks.

titleText.ttltext: Vitamin D receptor polymorphisms and melanoma (Review)

organizations: Department of Dermatology, ‘Iuliu Haţieganu’ University of Medicine and Pharmacy

paras: Melanoma represents the most aggressive skin cancer, with an unpredictable and often treatment resistant behavior. The etiology of melanoma is multifactorial and includes both environmental and genetic factors. Recent evidence indicates that vitamin D has a role in the development and progression of melanoma. The biologically active form of vitamin D/1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 acts by binding to a intranuclear receptor; vitamin D receptor (VDR). Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the vitamin D receptor gene may alter the expression or the function of the VDR protein leading to various diseases, including melanoma. More than 600 SNPs have been identified in the VDR gene, but only a few have been @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end in relation to melanoma risk: FokI, TaqI, BsmI, ApaI, Cdx2, EcoRV, and BglI. Individual studies carried on small cohorts of patients reported controversial results. In an attempt to clarify the available data in the literature on this subject, we elaborated a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end in which we @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end the relationship between VDR gene polymorphisms and melanoma risk and progression. We concluded that vitamin D pathway is important for the pathogenesis and the progression of cutaneous melanoma, illustrating the gene-environment interactions, but well-designed prospective studies that include data on both genotypes and phenotypes of vitamin D metabolism are essential in order to understand the mechanisms underlying the association between vitamin D and melanoma.

titleText.ttltext: Immunoglobulin replacement for secondary immunodeficiency after B-cell targeted therapies in autoimmune rheumatic disease: @hit_startSystematic literature review@hit_end

organizations: Department of Immunology, Frimley Health NHS Foundation Trust

paras: Background: Consensus guidelines are not available for the use of immunoglobulin replacement therapy (IGRT) in patients developing iatrogenic secondary antibody deficiency following B-cell targeted therapy (BCTT) in autoimmune rheumatic disease. Objectives: To evaluate the role of IGRT to manage hypogammaglobulinemia following BCTT in autoimmune rheumatic disease (AIRD). Methods: Using an agreed search string we performed a systematic literature search on @hit_startMedline@hit_end with @hit_startPubmed@hit_end as vendor. We limited the search to English language papers with abstracts published over the last 10 years. Abstracts were screened for original data regarding hypogammaglobulinemia following BCTT and the use of IGRT for hypogammaglobulinemia following BCTT. We also searched current recommendations from national/international organisations including British Society for Rheumatology, UK Department of Health, American College of Rheumatology, and American Academy of Asthma, Allergy and Immunology. Results: 222 abstracts were identified. Eight papers had original relevant data that met our search criteria. These studies were largely retrospective cohort studies with small patient numbers receiving IGRT. The literature highlights the induction of a sustained antibody deficiency, risk factors for hypogammaglobulinemia after BCTT including low baseline serum IgG levels, how to monitor patients for the development of hypogammaglobulinemia and the limited evidence available on intervention thresholds for commencing IGRT. Conclusion: The benefit of BCTT needs to be balanced against the risk of inducing a sustained secondary antibody deficiency. Consensus guidelines would be useful to enable appropriate assessment prior to and following BCTT in preventing and diagnosing hypogammaglobulinemia. Definitions for symptomatic hypogammaglobulinemia, intervention thresholds and treatment targets for IGRT, and its cost-effectiveness are required.
